important_phrase: Crude oil production in   the District edged up in late February and March
Permanent hiring remained weak
Some employers indicated that public policy   uncertainty had contributed to some reticence to hire permanent workers
The flow of bank credit to businesses   remained subdued
The majority of District   manufacturers reported that new orders increased and production levels improved
Homebuilders reported   improved new home sales across the region, and that construction activity   increased modestly from very low levels
District merchants   indicated an improvement in traffic and sales in March
Business conditions continue to improve in the First District
Virtually all contacts continue to express   concerns regarding rising health care costs
Condo sales also increased significantly in   Massachusetts and New Hampshire compared to February 2009
" All respondents are cautiously optimistic in their outlook
Hog   and cattle prices increased, but milk prices decreased
Construction, however, remained weak
Pass-through of cost pressures to downstream prices   was limited
Credit conditions improved from the   previous reporting period
Labor market conditions improved slightly from the   previous reporting period
Demand remained weak for nonresidential construction
Consumer spending increased in March
In   general, capital expenditures showed a modest improvement
Sales figures from   District retailers and auto dealers showed a moderate improvement
Interest rates were steady
Capacity utilization continued a slow upward   trend
In general, new home sales improved slightly   during the past six weeks and on a year-over-year basis
Vendor and store pricing has been relatively stable
There is concern that   gas-directed drilling will decline in the second half of the year
Respondents in high-tech manufacturing, retail, residential real   estate, energy and staffing and transportation services cited continued   improvement in demand
On-highway prices for diesel and gasoline followed suit, rising nearly 20   cents per gallon
Deposit growth has been relatively flat, and lending   standards remain tight
Paper manufacturing firms cited flat to rising demand
Commercial property sales activity picked up from very low levels
Outlooks remain guarded but   contacts expect continued improvement in sales throughout the year
Agricultural conditions improved since the   last survey period
Energy activity expanded further, but   natural gas production was expected to ease with slower summer demand
District manufacturers reported   additional increases in prices paid for raw materials
Bankers reported lower loan demand, stable   deposits, and an unchanged outlook for loan quality
Manufacturing production improved to near year-ago levels as slightly slower   growth at non-durable goods plants was offset by stronger durable goods   production
Construction supply   firms anticipated stronger sales for new construction materials as well as   higher consumer demand for home improvement supplies
Consumer spending rebounded in March as   customer traffic improved with warmer weather
Agricultural activity increased
The Ninth District economy grew moderately since the last report
Price increases were moderate
Architects indicated flat   activity at low levels
Commercial real estate was flat at low levels
Consumer spending increased   modestly
Districts reported   mixed results in agriculture
Many Districts reported increased   activity in housing markets from low levels
Richmond reported that average wages edged higher in March   in the services sector, but declined slightly in manufacturing
Demand for consumer   credit decreased in New York and increased slightly in Philadelphia
However,   for construction-related goods, Chicago and Dallas reported mixed conditions,   Boston reported flat activity and St Louis reported decreases
Commercial real estate activity was slow across the nation
Tourism conditions also improved during the reporting period
Manufacturing-sector   contacts report improved activity
Bankers also reported   decreased demand for refinancing
Looking at business conditions more generally, contacts outside the   manufacturing sector continue to describe conditions as stable or rising   modestly
Commercial real estate markets were steady to softer since the last report
Credit conditions for car buyers have continued to   improve, though floor-plan credit (for dealers) remains tight
Retailers expect sales to expand modestly as consumer   confidence is slowly restored
Retailers reported mostly flat   selling prices
Total outstanding loan volume at most of the   Third District banks contacted for this report has been level or has declined   slightly since the last Beige Book
One said, "Business is better than a year ago, but not exciting," and   another said, "There is a slow, steady gain

"
Nonresidential real estate firms indicated that leasing and construction   activity remained slow
Third District auto dealers reported an improved pace of sales in March   compared with February
Nevertheless, winter wheat was reported to be in mostly fair-to-good   condition in South Carolina and Wst Virginia
Retail sales improved, despite weak sales of big-ticket items
Average wages edged higher in March in the service   sector, but declined slightly in manufacturing
Banking activity was generally mixed, but with   more signs of improvements than in our last assessment
Port activity over the last few months was up slightly

"
Commercial real estate activity picked up slightly since our last report
Retail sales rebounded since our last report,   owing in part to a slower decline in big-ticket sales
Demand   remained strong for agricultural producers but was mixed for providers of   natural resources used for energy production
Economic activity in the Twelfth District continued to improve modestly   during the reporting period of late February into early April
Upward price pressures were limited on   net during the reporting period
District banking contacts reported   that loan demand was largely stable or up slightly compared with previous   reporting periods
Demand improved modestly for struggling companies in the metal   fabrication and wood products sectors, although capacity utilization remained at   extremely low levels
The pace of home sales remained mixed across areas   but appeared largely stable overall, while home prices edged up further in some   parts of the District
Retailers of furniture,   appliances, and electronic items noted improved sales
